story.kicker_image_caption: Environmentalist Sunita Narain at the launch of her book, Why I should be Tolerant.
story.storykicker: The book release was accompanied by a forthright conversation on the politics of environment and development, led by panelists Raj Chengappa, Group Editorial Director (Publishing), India Today Group, Bibek Debroy, member of NITI Aayog, and Ravish Kumar, NDTV anchor.
story.storybody:
AS the world grapples with an urgent environment crisis, Sunita Narain, Director General of the Centre for Science and Environment and Editor of fortnightly magazine, Down To Earth, launched her book Why I Should Be Tolerant at the India Habitat Centre on Saturday evening.

The book release was accompanied by a forthright conversation on the politics of environment and development, led by panelists Raj Chengappa, Group Editorial Director (Publishing), India Today Group, Bibek Debroy, member of NITI Aayog, and Ravish Kumar, NDTV anchor.

The conversation threw light on issues of sustainability, water shortage, forest conservation and what Narain called the 'environmentalism of the poor'.

THE INCONVENIENT TRUTH

Chengappa spoke of the growth of environmental journalism. He said more meaningful work needs to be done on pressing environmental matters.

Stressing on the power of change through technology, Chengappa asserted, "If we have to change the narrative, it has to start from people first. We have greater opportunity today to disseminate solutions to a wide audience. We need to translate the work on issues of forest, environment, health, poverty, water and circulate it to a wider audience."

"The issue of drought should scare us today," said Narain. "Yet, we do not hear about it. The only time we heard about it was during the IPL," she stated, adding, "This is the inconvenient truth that we do not want to come into our bedroom. We are so unaware. Today, we are more bubble wrapped in the views we want to listen to."

Also read: Ten thousand cattle die daily in Bundelkhand: NGO
